Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Voting, King said in an interview, gives “a little bit of your strength back and a little bit of your voice back. Being able to vote, being able to have a say in what happens in your society, in your state, is extremely important.”
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: TJ King had candidates and causes to support, but couldn’t vote in Nebraska’s last election; he came off probation in August after serving time for drug and theft convictions.

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: At least 14 states have introduced proposals this year focused on restoration of voting rights, according to the Brennan Center for Justice.

An Oregon proposal would allow felons to vote while incarcerated. A Tennessee bill would automatically restore voting rights once a sentence is completed, except for a small group of crimes. Texas legislation would restore voting rights to those on probation or parole.
“Restoring voting rights really is an issue where we’ve seen bipartisan momentum,”
Sourcing Table.Title of Source: Counsel for the Democracy program at the Brennan Center

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: More than 4.6 million people are disenfranchised in the United States because of felony convictions, according to the Sentencing Project, which studies the issue and advocates for restoration of voting rights for former felons.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: studies the issue and advocates for restoration of voting rights for former felons

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: In Nebraska, nearly 18,000 people are unable to vote because of felony convictions, said the Sentencing Project’s director of advocacy, Nicole Porter. That includes 7,072 who fall under the two-year wait requirement and are currently unable to cast a ballot.
Sourcing Table.Title of Source: Director of Advocacy, The Sentencing Project

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: “You’re civically dead and you can’t vote for the people who are levying those taxes,”
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: of Civic Nebraska, part of a large coalition of groups supporting the measure

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Nebraska is alone in requiring a general waiting period beyond imprisonment and release from parole or probation, said Margaret Love, co-founder and director of the Collateral Consequences Resource Center, which keeps a 50-state database on restoration of rights.
Sourcing Table.Title of Source: Co-founder and Director, Collateral Consequences Resource Center
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: keeps a 50-state database on restoration of rights

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: “When people get out of our system, they’ve got to feel engaged in their community, and the number one way for a person to feel engaged in their community is to be able to vote for the leadership of that community,”
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: author of the bill; represents parts of Omaha with strong minority populations

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: “I do think that hopefully the waiting period reinforces the fact that voting is something very special, and hopefully that will be part of the things that an individual would consider if they’re tempted to break the law again,”
Sourcing Table.Title of Source: Member, University of Nebraska Board of Regents
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: speaking as an individual and not on behalf of the university; lone dissenter from among the nearly 20 witnesses who spoke on Wayne’s bill

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: “I felt so hopeless and helpless not being able to have my voice heard in this last election,”
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: TJ King had candidates and causes to support, but couldn’t vote in Nebraska’s last election; he came off probation in August after serving time for drug and theft convictions.

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: “I don’t have a say in anything that goes on in my country because I’m a felon,”
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: among the more than 10,000 people in Nebraska who has no right to vote because they haven’t completed their sentences; has obtained graduate degrees and served in a variety of volunteer roles; set up her own nonprofit and is executive director of Q.U.E.E.N.S Butterfly House
was paroled in 2015 after serving more than four years on assault and other charges; now married with two small children and owns his own business
